title: How is life in the Thar Desert? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you're asking about part of Thar in Sindh, Pakistan, then I may give the best answer here as I just came back from a relief trip to Thar.  Thar is 400km (9hrs drive) away from Karachi, Pakistan. But in every way its locked 1000 years ago.  Karachi, Pakistan to S62-791, Wāori, Pakistan - Google Maps Here's how a typical home in Thar looks like, this single room koopa (local name) consists of everything a family needs like place to cook, sleep etc. The walls are made of mud bricks and plastered with mud. The roof is made with grass found in the region. Roof gets worn out in a few years and need repairs.   Main source of food for people is livestock and a few vegetables that grow in the region. It's been more than 18 months since it rained there, causing the water level to  decline by many 100 feet. Here's a short list of the major issues I saw there, Scarce Water - 2 members of each family are dedicated to fetch water. Alongwith Camel/Donkeys who could pull the rope from 250ft - 500ft. Nobody until 2014 thought of working on water pumps to make their lives easier. This would free these 2 persons, who can get some work to reduce poverty. I was told that people wash clothes when it rains.Highly Contaminated Water - Whatever water there is, its hazardous for drinking. People, animals drink the same water causing bone and tissue damages and several diseases. There's no treatment plant in the region.Extremely Fast Aging - A 25yrs old male has the skin wrinkles like a 50 yrs old. Old people can't even stand. Teeth start decaying from the age of 5. All due to contaminated water.Cut From Modern Civilization - Chchro, Sindh which is the closest bigger city is a very small town. Soon after Chachro, roads cease to exist. Only 4WDs have access to far of region. In case of emergency a trip to city costs PKR.4,000/- where people don't even have a PKR.100/-.Beauty of Thar Thar is blessed with beauty in its own way. Peacocks can be seen roaming around freely.     I'll edit this answer for more details, later.

Hello My friend A “simple” life is not necessarily an easy one. The Thar Desert, or Great Indian Desert, is an arid region that forms a natural boundary between India and Pakistan. A relatively large area, it spreads across four Indian states (Gujarat, Haryana, Punjab, and Rajasthan) and two Pakistani states. The Thar Desert is the most densely populated desert in the world, with 83 people per square km. This population lives in small villages, far apart from each other. The people are often nomadic: moving when their sparse water supply dries up. In most villages, the familial generations live together in one complex, and any money earned by family members becomes the common property of the family as a whole. A walk around the small village of Khuri, within the boundaries of Desert National Park, and only 45 km from the World Heritage city of Jaisalmer, demonstrates how little people make do with.
